maml:description.maml:para: Gets the memory resources allocated to one or more Virtual Machines.
Gets the memory resources allocated to one or more Virtual Machines.

The Virtual Machine(s) to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified the information will be returned for all VMs on the server.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer,, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.

The Virtual Machine(s) to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified the information will be returned for all VMs on the server.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
VMs can be piped into Get-VMMemory.
MSVM_MemorySettingData object.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets Key/Value pairs for one or more Virtual Machines.
Hyper-V provides an Integration Component to move a small amount of data between the registry in a guest VM and the host. This data is in the form of Keys (names) and associated Values..

The Virtual Machine(s) to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified the information will be returned for all VMs on the server.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.

The Virtual Machine(s) to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified the information will be returned for all VMs on the server.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
VMs can be piped into Get-VMKVP.
Objects which properties reflecting the Key/Value Pairs.

maml:alert.maml:para: The values sent Automatically to the child VM can be found in HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Virtual Machine\guest\Parameters.
The values sent Programmatically to the child VM can be found in HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Virtual Machine\External.
Those sent by the Child VM are in HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Virtual Machine\auto.
If the VM isn't running its Key/Value Pair Exchange Service does NOT persist the values. So stopped VMs won't return anything !.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns "Windows Server (R) 2008 Enterprise" - the OS that VM is running.
Returns the Key/Value pairs sent back by all the VMs on the Server James-2008.
Returns the Key/Value pairs for running VMs on the local Server.
Gets the Key/Value pairs for VMs on the local server, then uses Ping.exe to test the connection to the IPv4 address of each.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the memory resources allocated to one or more Virtual Machines.

Sets the memory resources allocated to one or more Virtual Machines. Dynamic memory was introduced in Server 2008-R2 SP1, and is managed with the -Limit, -Weight, -BufferPecentage and -Dynamic options.

The Virtual Machine(s) to modify. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.

Specifies the amount of memory that should be allocated to the Virtual Machine at start-up. For machines without dynamic memory enabled this quantity never changes. For machines with dynamic memory this is both the initial amount ("Virtual Quantity") and the Reserved amount ("Reservation"). The GUI interface can't set these to different values, and doing so is assumed to be unsupported. If greater than 2MB it is assumed to be expressed in bytes, otherwise it is treaded as MB. For clarity in scripts it has an alias MemoryInBytes.

This Parameter is ignored unless -Dynamic is specified. The maximum amount of memory that may be consumed by the virtual system. On a system without dynamic memory this is equal to Memory. With dynamic memory it sets the ceiling for memory allocation. If greater than 2MB it is assumed to be expressed in bytes, otherwise it is treaded as MB.

This Parameter is ignored unless -Dynamic is specified. Defines the memory allocation weighting value for a VM. After all reserves have been met, the remaining memory of the hosting platform will be allocated to virtual systems based on their relative weights. Prior to Server 2008-R2 SP1 this value was ignored, but had a maximum of 1,000. Server 2008-R2 SP1 uses this value with a maximum of 10,000. The default is 1,000 to avoid errors when used with older systems. For VMs using dynamic memory it is highly recommended that you specify the weight explicitly..

This Parameter is ignored unless -Dynamic is specified. For a VM with dynamic memory enabled, defines the amount of extra memory that should be reserved at runtime, as a percentage of the total memory that the Virtual Machine is thought to need. This property can be in the range of 5 to 2000, the default is 20 (as it is in the GUI).
Specifies that the VM should use the dynamic memory feature. This is not available in Server 2008, or Server 2008-R2 before SP1.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.

The Virtual Machine(s) to modify. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.

Specifies the amount of memory that should be allocated to the Virtual Machine at start-up. For machines without dynamic memory enabled this quantity never changes. For machines with dynamic memory this is both the initial amount ("Virtual Quantity") and the Reserved amount ("Reservation"). The GUI interface can't set these to different values, and doing so is assumed to be unsupported. If greater than 2MB it is assumed to be expressed in bytes, otherwise it is treaded as MB. For clarity in scripts it has an alias MemoryInBytes.

This Parameter is ignored unless -Dynamic is specified. The maximum amount of memory that may be consumed by the virtual system. On a system without dynamic memory this is equal to Memory. With dynamic memory it sets the ceiling for memory allocation. If greater than 2MB it is assumed to be expressed in bytes, otherwise it is treaded as MB.

This Parameter is ignored unless -Dynamic is specified. Defines the memory allocation weighting value for a VM. After all reserves have been met, the remaining memory of the hosting platform will be allocated to virtual systems based on their relative weights. Prior to Server 2008-R2 SP1 this value was ignored, but had a maximum of 1,000. Server 2008-R2 SP1 uses this value with a maximum of 10,000. The default is 1,000 to avoid errors when used with older systems. For VMs using dynamic memory it is highly recommended that you specify the weight explicitly..

This Parameter is ignored unless -Dynamic is specified. For a VM with dynamic memory enabled, defines the amount of extra memory that should be reserved at runtime, as a percentage of the total memory that the Virtual Machine is thought to need. This property can be in the range of 5 to 2000, the default is 20 (as it is in the GUI).
Specifies that the VM should use the dynamic memory feature. This is not available in Server 2008, or Server 2008-R2 before SP1.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
VMs can be piped into Set-VMMemory.
Updated MSVM_MemorySettingData object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Allocates 1GB of memory to all of the VMs on the local server with a name that starts with "CORE-".
Allocates 1.5GB of memory to the VM named Tenby on the server JAMES-2008.
Enables Dynamic memory on all machines whose names start with "Server". Setting the upper limit of memory to 2GB, a 25% buffer and a relative weight of 8000.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the CPU Resources allocated to one or more Virtual Machines.
Sets the CPU Resources allocated to one or more Virtual Machines.

The Virtual Machine(s) to modify. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
The Number of Virtual Processors to assign to the VM. It must be in the range 1-4. It can not be greater than the number of physical cores in the host. Some OSes support fewer processors..
The maximum time this processor is allowed to use. A VM defaults to a limit of 100% unless configured otherwise.
Amount of CPU time reserved for a VM. A VM defaults to a reservation of 0% unless configured otherwise.
Relative Weighting used to assign CPU time to this VM when the host processor is fully utilized.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.

The Number of Virtual Processors to assign to the VM. It must be in the range 1-4. It can not be greater than the number of physical cores in the host. Some OSes support fewer processors..
The maximum time this processor is allowed to use. A VM defaults to a limit of 100% unless configured otherwise.
Amount of CPU time reserved for a VM. A VM defaults to a reservation of 0% unless configured otherwise.
Relative Weighting used to assign CPU time to this VM when the host processor is fully utilized.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables or disables Integration Components on one or more Virtual Machines.
Enables or disables Integration Components on one or more Virtual Machines.

The Virtual Machine(s) to modify. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
The Name(s) of the Integration Component(s) to be modified. Only the start of the name needs to specified as a Wildcard is applied to the end of the name.
The Text "Running" or "Stopped" or the values 0 or 1 may be passed.

maml:description.maml:para: Synchronizes the configuration of a VM across all members of a cluster.

If the configuration of a clustered VM is changed on the node where it is resident, it is necessary to tell the cluster to update its information so that all nodes are consistent. If this is not done VMs may not be able to migrate. If the FailoverClusters Module has not been imported this command generates a warning.

The Virtual Machine(s) to synchronise. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is passed all VMs will be synchronised.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE.It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.

The Virtual Machine(s) to synchronise. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is passed all VMs will be synchronised.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
Adds a new RemoteFX graphics controller to a VM.

Server 2008 R2-SP1 introduced accelerated graphics controllers. These need to be added explicitly to VMs. This command adds the RemoteFX controller to a VM. A VM may only have a single controller and attempting to add a second one will cause an error. Set-VMRemoteFXController is safer to use because it will add or modify as appropriate.

The Virtual Machine(s) to which graphics cards should be added. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards cannot be used.

Remote FX supports 4 resolutions listed below. The Default is 1024x768 The RemoteFxResoultion ENUM allows either the text below or the associated number to be specified Display1024x768 = 0, Display1280x1024 = 1, Display1600x1200 = 2, Display1920x1200 = 3.
Remote FX supports clients with 1 to 4 monitors. The default is 1.

The Virtual Machine(s) to which graphics cards should be added This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.

Remote FX supports 4 resolutions listed below. The Default is 1024x768 The RemoteFxResoultion ENUM allows either the text below or the associated number to be specified Display1024x768 = 0, Display1280x1024 = 1, Display1600x1200 = 2, Display1920x1200 = 3.
Remote FX supports clients with 1 to 4 monitors. The default is 1.
Virtual Machines may be piped into Add-VMRemoteFXController.
A WMI object representing the newly created controller.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a RemoteFx controller supporting 2 monitors with 1920x1200 resolution to the VM named tenby.

Adds a RemoteFx controller supporting a single monitor with 1920x1200 to Stopped VMs named "WIN7" The controller will support a single monitor and the resolution is set using the [RemoteFxResoultion] enum.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies or adds a RemoteFX graphics controller on a VM.
If a VM already has a RemoteFX graphics controller, Set-VMRemoteFXController modifies its settings. If not, Set-VMRemoteFXController calls Add-VMRemoteFXController to install one.

The Virtual Machine(s) to which graphics cards should be added. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards cannot be used.

Remote FX supports 4 resolutions listed below. The RemoteFxResoultion ENUM allows either the text below or the associated number to be specified Display1024x768 = 0, Display1280x1024 = 1, Display1600x1200 = 2, Display1920x1200 = 3.
Remote FX supports clients with 1 to 4 monitors..
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
The Resource Allocation Settings Data WMI object describing a controller to be modified. This can be passed instead of passing the VM WMI object or VM Name/Server Name.

Remote FX supports 4 resolutions listed below. The RemoteFxResoultion ENUM allows either the text below or the associated number to be specified Display1024x768 = 0, Display1280x1024 = 1, Display1600x1200 = 2, Display1920x1200 = 3.
Remote FX supports clients with 1 to 4 monitors..

The Virtual Machine(s) to which graphics cards should be added This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.

Remote FX supports 4 resolutions listed below. The Default is 1024x768 The RemoteFxResoultion ENUM allows either the text below or the associated number to be specified Display1024x768 = 0, Display1280x1024 = 1, Display1600x1200 = 2, Display1920x1200 = 3.
Remote FX supports clients with 1 to 4 monitors. The default is 1.
The Resource Allocation Settings Data WMI object describing a controller to be modified. This can be passed instead of passing the VM WMI object or VM Name/Server Name.
Virtual Machines may be piped into Set-VMRemoteFXController.
A WMI object representing the newly created controller.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the RemoteFx controller on the VM named Tenby to support 2 monitors. If there is no controller one will be created using the default resolution.
Gets all pre-existing RemoteFX controllers on the local server and resets their resolution to 1600x1200.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the RemoteFx graphics controller(s) for one or more VM(s).
Gets the RemoteFx graphics controller(s) for one or more VM(s).

The Virtual Machine(s) to check This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified all VMs are checked.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards cannot be used.

The Virtual Machine(s) to check This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is specified all VMs are checked.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
Virtual Machines may be piped into Get-VMRemoteFXController.
WMI object(s) representing the graphics controller(s).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns a WMI object representing the RemoteFX Controller on VM named "Tenby" (if there is one).

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the RemoteFX display controller(s) from one or more VMs.
Removes the RemoteFX display controller(s) from one or more VMs. If no VM is present on the specified VM, the command completes without error.

The Virtual Machine(s) from which the graphics card(s) should be removed. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -WhatIf, -Confirm, -Verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards cannot be used.

The Virtual Machine(s) from which the graphics card(s) should be removed. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards cannot be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE.It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.
Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out.
Virtual Machines may be piped into Remove-VMRemoteFXController.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes the RemoteFX Controller from the VM named "Tenby".
Gets all VMs in a Stopped state on the cluster nodes "node1" and "Node2" and removes any RemoteFxControllers installed on them.
